DOC.TEXT: The stock market headed higher today, bidding again to mount a yearend rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 14.50 to 2,723.76 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 698 up, 431 down and 564 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 36.79 million shares at midmorning. Analysts found little in the economic news to stir the market out of its recent lethargy. Interest rates were narrowly mixed in the credit markets. But traders still appeared to be hopeful that stocks might gather strength in early 1990, once yearend maneuvering by investors for tax and portfolio reporting purposes was out of the way. Germany Fund jumped 1[ to 16 as the West German market soared to new highs, propelled by enthusiasm over the ascendance of democracy in Eastern Europe. Hilton Hotels fell 5| to 84[ on a report that efforts to sell the company had attracted lower bids than had been predicted. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up \ at 40\; Merck, up ] at 76[; Sears Roebuck, up ] at 37}, and Union Carbide, up ] at 23{. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .71 to 192.43. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .40 at 371.20.
